title: Food tester's visit 'provides feast of opportunities' (Fuseworks)
text:
Tumblr Lincoln experts were getting a taste of food testing on a massive scale in one of New Zealand’s most important export markets recently. 
Lincoln University was visited by senior management from China Food and Drug Administration’s (CDFA) National Institute for Food and Drug Control (NIFDC), Deputy Director-General Dr Youchun Wang, Director of Institute for Food and Cosmetics Control within NIFDC, Dr Qingsheng Zhang, and Dr Wenchen Liu, Principal Member of CFDA’s Planning and Finance Unit. 
NIFDC has over 800 staff spread across more than 50 units testing foods, pharmaceutical products, biological products, medical devices, cosmetics, and reference standards and drug safety evaluation. 
It has more than 10,000 testing instruments and pieces of measuring equipment, and performs 800 different testing techniques. Each year more than 13,000 batches of drugs, food and cosmetics are tested and more than 2900 reference standards are distributed by NIFDC. 
Lincoln University’s Business Development Manager Dr Samuel Yu says the visit is a great ways for scientists, international regulatory authorities, and businesses and companies to discuss together the issues faced in the food testing and export sectors, and see how to design pathways to problem-solve potential challenges. 
"Establishing and building these connections and relationships becomes increasing vital, as New Zealand is a large exporter of foods and other high-value products, and being able to participate with the regulatory authorities that we export into, is an important way to build understanding about their requirements." 
It can also help the ability of New Zealand and Lincoln students, and scientists, to formulate solutions that can have a global impact, Dr Yu says. 
The group was officially welcomed by Dean of Agricultural and Life Sciences (AGLS), Professor Bruce McKenzie, followed by an overview of Lincoln University. Lincoln toxicology specialist, Associate Professor Ravi Gooneratne, and Food Safety and Microbiologist specialist, Dr Malik Hussain, also presented their collaborations in southern China, and discussed with NIFDC the latest contamination trends in New Zealand. 
Yili Oceania Dairy’s R&D Manager, Dr Philip Wescombe, based on the Lincoln University campus, was also invited by NIFDC to participate in the discussions.
